Titan's Potential Internal Ocean Remains Uncertain
item.description: Recent findings have cast doubt on the hypothesis that Titan, Saturn's largest moon, possesses a global liquid ocean beneath its icy surface. While the idea of an ocean rich in ammonia and other compounds has been supported by Cassini's data, a new study challenges this notion by analyzing Titan's response to tidal forces. The original hypothesis suggested a liquid ocean nearly 250 km thick, but new research indicates that instead of a global ocean, Titan might have multiple layers of different types of ice, with potential liquid water pockets. Titan's unique environment, including its methane lakes and thick atmosphere, makes it a fascinating target for NASA's Dragonfly mission, launching in 2028. This mission will explore Titan's dunes and study a region known as the Selk crater, which may have once hosted liquid water and complex organic molecules, important for astrobiological research. item.title: Forest City: A $30 Billion Real Estate Failure in Malaysia
item.description: Forest City, an ambitious real estate project in Malaysia, was designed to house 750,000 residents and attract foreign investment, particularly from China. Launched in 2006, the development faced numerous challenges, including political changes, stricter regulations on foreign property ownership, and the COVID-19 pandemic. As of early 2025, the population of the city is a fraction of the expected number, with only around 10,000 people living in the area. Despite over $30 billion invested, the island city remains almost deserted, with many buildings and shops empty. Forest City is owned largely by China's Country Garden, which struggled with massive debt, and a local Malaysian investment fund. While the city is being maintained to look pristine, it has faced ecological and diplomatic concerns due to its location in the Strait of Malacca, a critical maritime passage. item.title: Morocco Expands Its Military Modernization Through Israeli Arms Purchases
item.description: Morocco continues to expand its military capabilities by purchasing strategic armaments from Israel, signaling a deepening defense relationship between Rabat and Tel Aviv. The article notes that Israel’s defense industry has broadened its client base from Southeast Asia to North Africa, with Morocco validating a new order for heavy artillery within the year. It mentions deployments of Israeli-made equipment in other regional conflicts, illustrating that international criticism of the Gaza war has not disrupted Israeli arms exports. Leading defense companies such as Elbit Systems and Rafael are highlighted as key players in this growth. Morocco reportedly made a significant investment, signing an agreement estimated at 150 to 200 million euros for ATMOS artillery systems, supplementing existing acquisitions like the PULS rocket launcher and the Barak MX air defense shield. item.title: The Health Crisis: The Consequences of Privatization and the Collapse of Public Healthcare
item.description: Michael Moore's documentary *Sicko* may be years old, but its relevance and impact have only grown since its release. In a recent blog post, the author reflects on the critical themes of the documentary and shares a poignant excerpt that highlights the dangers of the privatization of healthcare. The excerpt features a doctor who passionately discusses how the current trend of privatizing healthcare is leading to preventable deaths. As public healthcare systems collapse under the pressure of underfunding, more and more individuals are unable to access essential care. The doctor warns that this isn't an accidental outcome, but a deliberate policy shift that prioritizes private profits over human lives. Long waitlists, overcrowded primary care, and understaffed emergency services are just some of the deadly consequences of this shift. item.title: Impact of Satellite Megaconstellations on Space-Based Observatories
item.description: In recent years, the deployment of massive satellite constellations such as Starlink has raised concerns about their impact on astronomical observations, including those conducted from space. Initially, some suggested that moving telescopes to low Earth orbit (LEO) could solve the issue. However, a recent study published in Nature by Alejandro Borlaff, Pamela Marcum, and Steve Howell confirms that even space-based telescopes in LEO are increasingly affected. Currently, about 9,400 Starlink satellites orbit Earth, but projections suggest that by 2040 there could be up to 500,000 satellites, causing significant contamination of astronomical images. Already, 4.3% of Hubble Space Telescope images between 2018 and 2021 were affected. Newer satellites, such as Starlink v2 Mini, are larger and brighter, exacerbating the problem. Future wide-field and all-sky survey missions like NASA's SPHEREx, the Chinese Xuntian telescope, and the European ARRAKIHS could see up to 96% of their observations

item.title: Canada’s Controversial ‘Victims of Communism’ Monument Will Remove All Names
item.description: A year after its opening, Canada's Monument to the Victims of Communism in Ottawa is facing a major controversy over the names initially set to be inscribed on the memorial. A government report revealed that more than half of the 553 names planned for inclusion were linked to Nazi or fascist affiliations. As a result, the Department of Canadian Heritage has decided to remove all individual names and instead focus on thematic content that aligns with Canadian values of democracy and human rights. The monument, designed by architect Paul Raff, originally sought to commemorate the suffering of millions under communist regimes. However, its funding and connections to controversial groups, including Nazi collaborators, have sparked criticism. This shift in focus follows widespread backlash from Jewish organizations and media outlets who raised concerns about the individuals initially listed on the memorial. item.title: Airbus plans long-term move of mission-critical systems to a European sovereign cloud
item.description:
Airbus is preparing to launch a major procurement process to migrate some of its most sensitive and mission-critical applications to a digitally sovereign European cloud. The aerospace group plans to issue a request for proposals in early January, with a final decision expected before the summer. The contract, estimated to be worth more than €50 million, would run for up to ten years and is intended to offer long-term price predictability.
The systems targeted for migration include enterprise resource planning (ERP), manufacturing execution systems, customer relationship management (CRM), and product lifecycle management platforms that store aircraft design data. According to Catherine Jestin, Airbus’s executive vice president of digital, the information involved is extremely sensitive from both national and European perspectives, making digital sovereignty a core requirement. Airbus wants guarantees that its data remains under European control and is protected from extraterritorial l

item.title: EU debates restrictions on Russian assets amid concerns over private ownership
item.description: The European Union recently decided not to seize Russian assets directly but instead approved a loan to Ukraine backed collectively by the 27 member states. Earlier, EU leaders, including Ursula von der Leyen and Kersti Kaljulaid, had pushed for a more aggressive approach to confiscate Russian assets, but concerns over legal, financial, and ethical implications led to a reversal. One consideration, reported by the Berliner Zeitung, is that while the assets are formally state-owned, they may contain funds belonging to private individuals, some of whom could be Jewish. This raises complex questions about targeting sanctions without violating property rights or international law, drawing historical parallels to the seizure of Jewish assets during the Nazi era. The discussion highlights the EU’s balancing act between supporting Ukraine financially and avoiding actions that could be considered discriminatory or unlawful. item.title: Hotel guest leaves room in extreme mess after two-year stay, prompting cleanup and renovation concerns
item.description: A hotel in Changchun, China, reported a shocking housekeeping scenario after a guest, described as a hardcore online gamer, checked out following a two-year stay. Staff recounted that the guest was rarely seen outside the room, and several workers did not know what he looked like due to his limited movements. Upon checkout, staff discovered an enormous mess: a three-foot-deep mountain of toilet paper, food wrappers, bottles, and takeaway containers cluttered every surface. The bathroom was severely littered, with tissues and discarded items covering the sink, and a thick brown grime covering the floor. A table and two gaming chairs were buried under waste. Cleaning required three days of back-breaking work to disinfect and restore the room. Despite the severity, management indicated no police report and no immediate plans to pursue responsibility, noting the guest still owed fees totaling nearly £300. item.title: Low-cost mass production: the strategic shift redefining future warfare
item.description: This analysis argues that Western powers are driving a paradigm shift in military strategy toward affordable, mass-produced weapons, particularly drones, to sustain a protracted state of high-intensity competition. It highlights how France, under Emmanuel Chiva, merged military needs with private industry, pushing for civilian-to-military conversion and the stockpiling of strategic minerals. The piece contends that traditional high-cost, high-tech weapons are being deprioritized in favor of scalable, inexpensive platforms capable of operating in large quantities. The article notes a comparative advantage for Russia, which deploys vast numbers of inexpensive FPV drones daily, achieving precision and battlefield reach while costly unguided artillery loses relative efficacy. It references Ukraine as a case study where drones play a dominant role, suggesting that future battles will hinge on drone ubiquity and supply chains for mass production. item.title: European Commission discusses post-2035 rules for hybrids and range-extender vehicles amid pressure on the auto industry
item.description:
The article claims that the European Commission has reversed its previously announced plan to ban the sale of new cars with internal combustion engines from 2035, presenting the move as a major retreat from the EU’s climate agenda and a relief for the struggling European automotive industry. According to the text, this alleged decision would allow manufacturers to continue selling plug-in hybrid vehicles and electric cars equipped with gasoline-powered range extenders after 2035. The article frames the measure as provisional but politically significant, describing it as a capitulation driven by economic pressure, industrial decline, and growing competition from Chinese carmakers.
The piece emphasizes the difficult situation facing Europe’s automotive sector, noting that sales remain below pre-pandemic levels and exports are weakening. item.title: Minnesota Senate Bill Seeks to Include 'Trump Derangement Syndrome' in Mental Illness Definition
item.description: A bill introduced in the Minnesota Senate aims to modify the state's legal definition of mental illness by formally recognizing 'Trump Derangement Syndrome' (TDS) as a mental health condition. The proposed legislation, introduced during Minnesota's Ninety-Fourth Legislative Session, suggests amending Sections 245.462 and 245I.02 of the Minnesota Statutes to incorporate TDS alongside other recognized mental disorders. According to the bill, TDS is defined as an 'acute onset of paranoia' triggered by Donald Trump's policies and actions. Symptoms listed include intense verbal hostility toward Trump, difficulty distinguishing between policy disagreements and perceived pathological behavior, and acts of aggression toward Trump supporters or symbols associated with him. If passed, the bill would integrate TDS into the framework for case management and community mental health services. The measure is expected to provoke debate among lawmakers, with opposition likely from mental health experts

item.title: Germany Opts for U.S. MQ-9B SeaGuardian Drones Over European Alternatives
item.description: Germany has made a significant shift in its defense procurement strategy by approving the purchase of U.S. MQ-9B SeaGuardian drones for its Navy, moving away from European alternatives. The decision comes amid a broader defense spending spree, as the German Bundestag recently authorized over 50 billion euros for various military projects, including combat vehicles, artillery systems, and space-based assets. The MQ-9B SeaGuardian drones, manufactured by General Atomics, will be used for long-range reconnaissance and anti-submarine missions, supporting the German Navy's existing fleet of P-8A Poseidon aircraft. This acquisition effectively ends Germany’s involvement in the EuroDrone program, a European initiative led by Airbus for developing a medium-altitude long-endurance drone. Germany’s decision is seen as a blow to the European defense industry, especially given its historical leadership in the EuroDrone project and its use of Israeli-made drones in the past. item.title: EU's Sanctions on Jacques Baud: A Critique of Authoritarian Practices
item.description: This article reflects on the recent European Union sanctions imposed on Jacques Baud, a Swiss military historian and former intelligence officer, over alleged 'Russian propaganda.' The author, Martin Sonneborn, argues that these sanctions highlight the EU's increasing authoritarianism and disregard for the rule of law. Baud, who has written extensively on the Ukraine conflict, has been banned from entering EU territory and had his assets frozen despite having no financial ties to Russia. Sonneborn compares the EU's actions to a dictatorship, noting the lack of transparency, the inability for the accused to defend themselves, and the absence of legal processes. He also points out that similar repressive actions are being taken against others who dissent from the mainstream EU narrative on Ukraine and Gaza. Sonneborn criticizes Ursula von der Leyen's leadership, claiming the EU under her has strayed far from its founding principles of democracy and peace. The article ends with a philosop

item.title: The Congo Panorama: Colonial Propaganda and the Erasure of Belgian Atrocities
item.description:
The article examines how Belgium used cultural propaganda to conceal and normalize the brutal realities of its colonial rule in the Congo. It begins with King Leopold II’s personal acquisition of the Congo in the late 19th century and the international outrage provoked by widespread abuses, including forced labor, corporal punishment, and mass mutilations. Facing growing criticism, Belgian authorities sought to rehabilitate the country’s image through large-scale exhibitions that portrayed colonization as a benevolent and civilizing mission.
A central focus is the monumental artwork “Panorama of the Congo,” commissioned for the 1913 Ghent World’s Fair. Created by Alfred Bastien and Paul Mathieu, the massive circular painting presented an idealized vision of colonial life, emphasizing economic progress, missionary work, and harmony between Europeans and Congolese people. The explicit goal, as stated by organizers, was to make the public forget the scandals as quickly as possible.

item.title: Italian Deputy Prime Minister Criticizes the Impact of Sanctions on Russia on European Economies
item.description:
The article reports on statements made by Italy’s Deputy Prime Minister, Matteo Salvini, who strongly criticized the European Union’s sanctions against Russia, describing their overall impact on Europe as 'disastrous.' According to Salvini, the 19 sanctions packages implemented over nearly four years were intended to weaken Russia but instead have significantly harmed Western economies. He argued that these measures have contributed to economic decline across Europe and have notably driven up energy costs in Italy, placing additional pressure on households and businesses.
Salvini also warned against what he sees as the growing militarization of Europe, which he attributes to an exaggerated or 'phantom' threat posed by Russia. He questioned the strategic logic behind escalating military postures, suggesting that historical precedents demonstrate the futility of attempting to confront or defeat Russia through force. item.title: Globalized intifada? A critical examination of power, oppression, and technology in Western elites
item.description: This article, sourced from Rafael Poch de Feliu and featuring commentary by Jonathan Cook, argues that Western elites fear a globalized intifada not because of Jewish targets but because the idea itself challenges entrenched power structures. It frames the Palestinian struggle as emblematic of a broader anti-colonial and anti-elite resistance, suggesting that slogans like 'globalize the intifada' echo historical calls for people’s power against oppressive systems. The piece links modern surveillance tech, facial recognition, and militarized policing to a broader trend of control over everyday life, positing that these tools have been developed and tested in the occupied Palestinian territories. It further contends that Israel serves as a model for how elites might manage surplus populations in a resource-scarce, climate-threatened world, with dissent framed as antisemitic when directed at this dominant narrative. item.title: Logistics of the Great Pyramid: Insights from the Ro-She Khufu Harbour and Merer's Diary
item.description: The article explores the ancient harbour of Ro-She Khufu and the diary of Inspector Merer, shedding light on the logistics behind the construction of the Great Pyramid of Giza. Merer, a middle-ranking official, managed a team responsible for transporting massive limestone blocks from the Tura quarry to the Giza Plateau. His day-to-day records, preserved for over 4,500 years in Wadi al-Jarf, detail a sophisticated operation involving barges called imu, canals, and an artificial harbour basin to overcome the Nile floodplain's height difference. Ro-She Khufu, an engineering marvel, allowed the transportation of heavy stones using sluice gates and ramps, later complemented by mechanical pulley systems. The harbour served as an administrative and storage hub, accommodating workers, sailors, and officials like Vizier Ankhhaf. While limestone transport was documented, granite from Aswan posed additional logistical challenges due to its weight and distance. The diary provides crucial insight i

item.title: Karpathy predicts AI agents will need a decade to reach functional autonomy
item.description: OpenAI cofounder Andrej Karpathy expressed skepticism about the current state of AI agents during his appearance on the Dwarkesh Podcast. Despite the hype surrounding AI in 2025, Karpathy emphasized that functional AI agents are still far from reality and will require about ten years to overcome significant limitations. He criticized current agents for lacking sufficient intelligence, multimodal capabilities, computer interaction skills, and continual learning abilities. Karpathy highlighted that AI agents often cannot remember instructions or improve over time, making them unreliable. While many investors hail 2025 as 'the year of the agent,' he warned against overestimating AI's current capabilities. Karpathy envisions AI as a collaborative tool that aids humans in tasks such as coding, rather than replacing them entirely. He prefers systems that guide users, verify actions, and facilitate learning rather than simply delivering pre-generated solutions. Other experts, such as Quintin

item.title: China Tests Domestic EUV Lithography Prototype Developed with Reverse-Engineered Components
item.description: According to sources close to Reuters, China has developed a functional prototype of an EUV lithography machine, currently undergoing testing. This achievement is attributed to Chinese companies, including Huawei, who successfully reverse-engineered ASML's advanced EUV scanners and built a domestic version using second-hand parts. The prototype reportedly occupies a full factory floor, similar in size to modern High-NA EUV machines from ASML. The Chinese government initially targeted 2028 for producing working chips with this machine, but progress suggests it may come sooner. Huawei is leading this initiative to establish a complete domestic AI and semiconductor supply chain, reducing dependence on foreign technologies. The prototype employs laser-induced discharge plasma (LDP) technology to generate 13.5 nm EUV light, offering potential advantages over ASML’s laser-produced plasma (LPP) systems, such as reduced footprint, improved energy efficiency, and lower costs. item.title: Occupational Radiation Exposure and the Overlooked Risk of Indoor Radon in Spain
item.description:
The article discusses how public concern about radiation is often selective and poorly informed, focusing heavily on nuclear power plants or medical imaging while ignoring more common and sometimes more dangerous sources of ionizing radiation. The author begins by asking which workers in Spain receive the highest doses of ionizing radiation. Most people would assume radiology staff in hospitals or workers at nuclear power plants, both of whom are subject to strict legal exposure limits averaging 20 mSv per year. These limits are already several times higher than the natural background radiation received by the general population, which varies across Spain due to cosmic radiation and local geology.
However, the article highlights a surprising case: bank employees working in a specific branch in the A Coruña area who were exposed to extremely high concentrations of radon gas. Measurements reportedly reached 17,000 Bq/m³, leading to an estimated annual dose of about 428 mSv—far exceeding

item.title: Estonia Convicts Koos Leaders Over Pro-Russia Allegations Amid Crackdown on Dissent
item.description: An Estonian court has sentenced leaders of the Koos party to lengthy prison terms, accusing them of treason for allegedly working with Russia and posing a national security threat. Aivo Peterson, Koos cofounder, received a 14-year sentence, while Dmitri Rootsi and Andrei Andronov were sentenced to 11 years each. The defendants deny any ties to Russian intelligence, but the court did not accept their arguments. Prosecutors claimed the group issued proclamations supporting Russia’s foreign and security policies and deliberately aided Russia in activities against Estonia. The government has not presented evidence of direct Russian intelligence involvement, arguing instead that Koos advocates a pragmatic, neutral, and peaceful foreign policy, including calls for Estonia to withdraw from NATO and to disengage from the Ukraine conflict. The Koos platform also proposes Estonia’s withdrawal from the NATO-backed coalition supporting Ukraine. In Estonia and much of the EU, expressing opposition

item.title: IBM CEO questions the economic viability of large-scale AI data center investments
item.description: IBM CEO Arvind Krishna has raised concerns about the sustainability of the current investment trajectory in large-scale AI data centers. Speaking on The Verge's Decoder podcast, he highlighted that planned multi-gigawatt AI campuses could cost around $8 trillion cumulatively, requiring approximately $800 billion in annual profits just to service capital costs. Krishna emphasized that filling a one-gigawatt AI facility with hardware costs roughly $80 billion, and with companies planning tens to over 100 gigawatts in capacity, the financial burden grows exponentially. He noted that five-year refresh cycles for AI accelerators create compounding capital expenditures, as outdated hardware must be replaced due to rapid technological change and depreciation. Krishna also expressed skepticism about current LLM-centric architectures achieving AGI without new methods for knowledge integration. item.title: 2025 Physics Nobel Awarded for Macroscopic Quantum Tunneling and Energy Quantization
item.description: The 2025 Nobel Prize in Physics has been awarded to John Clarke, Michel H. Devoret, and John M. Martinis for their pioneering work on macroscopic quantum tunneling and energy quantization in electrical circuits. Their research demonstrated that quantum effects, previously observed only at the scale of individual particles, can manifest in systems containing billions of particles. The team designed an experiment using superconducting materials separated by an ultrathin insulating layer, known as a Josephson junction. By cooling the circuit to near absolute zero and performing highly precise measurements, they observed a collective quantum behavior in the circuit, where the system tunneled through an energy barrier without the classical energy required. Additionally, they confirmed that the system could only absorb or emit energy in discrete amounts, verifying the principle of energy quantization. item.title: Leaked Documents Reveal Israel’s Use of Legal Strategies to Influence International Justice
item.description: A recent leak of over two million documents from Israel’s Ministry of Justice (MoJ), covering the period from 2009 to spring 2023, exposes how Israel allegedly deployed legal strategies to protect officials and the state from international legal scrutiny. The leak, claimed by a group named “Anonymous for Justice” and reported in April 2024, is indexed and publicly searchable through the nonprofit Distributed Denial of Secrets (DDoS). Amnesty International’s Security Lab confirmed the documents appear authentic. The majority of the files originate from the Department of Special International Affairs, established in 2010 and headed by Roy Schöndorf, who previously worked on legal justifications for extrajudicial actions. The department’s official role was managing international legal proceedings related to counterterrorism, while also developing lawfare strategies to advance Israeli interests and counter perceived misuse of legal tools against Israel. item.title: Investigations Reveal Corruption Risks Within NATO's Procurement Agency Amid Ukraine Conflict
item.description: The NATO Support and Procurement Agency (NSPA), based in Luxembourg, is facing significant corruption allegations involving bid manipulation, leaking of confidential information, and opaque contract management. Italian internal audit chief Gerardo Bellantone, who was dismissed after reporting abuses, played a key role in exposing these issues. Other whistleblowers, including NSPA Human Resources Director Geneviève Machin, have accused top executives, including Director General Stacy Cummings, of favoritism and inaction regarding corruption. With contracts worth €9.5 billion under her management, Cummings faces criticism for influencing decisions while ignoring fraud. The NSPA is now under investigation by Eurojust and several European states, highlighting long-standing vulnerabilities in military procurement, historically prone to abuse. Comparisons are made to past scandals like the U.S. Operation Ill Wind and Belgium’s Agusta-Dassault case. The article also discusses how Western offi

item.title: China and Ethiopia: Building a New Model of Industrial and Political Partnership in Africa
item.description: The economic cooperation between China and Ethiopia has become a key example of how global power dynamics are shifting. Through large-scale infrastructure projects and industrial investments, China has helped transform Ethiopia into one of Africa’s most promising industrial hubs. Since joining the Belt and Road Initiative in 2013, Ethiopia has benefited from Chinese-financed projects such as the Addis Ababa–Djibouti railway, which drastically reduced freight transport times from three days to under twelve hours. This development has bolstered the country's export capacity and positioned it strategically in the Horn of Africa. Chinese companies and financial institutions — including the China Development Bank, Exim Bank of China, and firms like Huajian Group — have established industrial parks such as Hawassa and the Eastern Industry Zone, creating tens of thousands of jobs and fostering technology transfer. item.title: President Trump Faces Backlash for Mocking Rob Reiner After His Death
item.description: According to a report published by Zeteo on December 15, 2025, American filmmaker Rob Reiner and his wife, Michele Singer Reiner, were found stabbed to death in their Los Angeles home. The following day, President Donald Trump posted a controversial message online mocking the late director, referring to him as someone afflicted with 'Trump Derangement Syndrome.' The comments sparked immediate outrage across social and political circles, with even allies of the administration declining to publicly defend the statement. The White House did not respond to requests for comment. Authorities took the couple’s son into custody, though no official charges were announced at the time, and investigators classified the deaths as homicides. The incident comes during a period marked by tensions between Trump’s administration and outspoken critics in the entertainment industry. item.title: Lawmakers Warn Attorney General Pam Bondi Over Compliance With Epstein Files Release Deadline
item.description:
Attorney General Pam Bondi is facing intense political pressure from Democratic lawmakers over the Justice Department’s obligation to release the so-called Epstein Files by a court-mandated deadline. Representative Ro Khanna of California, a leading proponent of the Epstein Transparency Act, publicly warned that any attempt to conceal, excessively redact, or tamper with the documents could expose responsible officials to prosecution for obstruction of justice. His remarks were delivered in a video posted on X ahead of the 11:59 p.m. Friday deadline, emphasizing that no official, regardless of rank or political affiliation, would be immune from accountability.
Khanna stressed that the law requires a full and transparent release, allowing only limited redactions to protect victims’ identities or ongoing investigations. item.title: Legislative Palace of San Lázaro: History, Architecture, and Role in Mexico’s Congress
item.description:
The Legislative Palace of San Lázaro is the principal seat of Mexico’s legislative power and the permanent meeting place of the Chamber of Deputies, as well as the venue for joint sessions of the Congress of the Union. Located in eastern Mexico City near the historic center, the complex was built between 1979 and 1981 following a major political reform in 1977 that expanded the number of deputies, making the former legislative headquarters insufficient. The site previously housed the San Lázaro Railway Station, and its redevelopment formed part of a broader urban and public works program promoted during the administration of President José López Portillo.
Designed by prominent architects Pedro Ramírez Vázquez, Jorge Campuzano, and David Suárez, the building reflects minimalist and modern architectural styles. item.title: FBI Investigation in Colorado Springs Involved Undercover Surveillance and Alleged Entrapment of Racial Justice Activists
item.description:
The article details a secret FBI operation carried out in Colorado Springs during and after the 2020 racial justice protests sparked by the killing of George Floyd. According to reporting by The Intercept, the FBI, working through a Joint Terrorism Task Force with local police, used an undercover Colorado Springs police detective, April Rogers, to infiltrate left-wing and racial justice activist groups. Posing as a volunteer named “Chelsie,” Rogers gained the trust of activists at the Chinook Center, a community hub for organizing, and obtained access to internal records, emails, and personal relationships.
Once embedded, Rogers allegedly provided intelligence to the FBI and attempted to steer activists toward illegal activities, including gun-running schemes, mirroring tactics used by a paid FBI informant in Denver during the same period. item.title: Tesla organizes employee event in Berlin amid upcoming union vote
item.description: Tesla held a private event, called a “Giga-Event,” at its Gigafactory Berlin on December 2, featuring German rapper Kool Savas. The event appeared aimed at boosting employee morale but also served as a subtle anti-union campaign ahead of a critical work council election. During the performance, Savas attempted to hype the crowd by arriving on stage in a Cybertruck, changing lyrics in his songs to reference Tesla, and leading chants for Elon Musk. Employees reportedly remained unresponsive, creating an awkward atmosphere. Tesla management, including factory manager André Thierig, took the opportunity to criticize the IG Metall union while announcing a 4% wage increase. However, the union argues that salaries should rise by an additional 30% to match industry standards. IG Metall's chief, Otto, highlighted Tesla's long-standing strategy of encouraging employees to avoid unionizing in exchange for advancement opportunities, framing expansion plans as contingent on election results. item.title: Finland Publishes Annual Tax Records of Top Earners
item.description: Every November, Finland observes a unique tradition known as Tax Day, when the Finnish Tax Administration releases public data on incomes and taxes of the country's wealthiest individuals. This practice, rooted in the 'julkisuusperiaate' or 'principle of publicity', ensures transparency by allowing the public to access tax records. This year, the dataset included individuals earning over €150,000, roughly 1% of the population. At the top of the list was Mikko 'Miki' Kuusi, founder of Wolt and CEO of Deliveroo, with an income of €80.6 million, paying €39.7 million in taxes. Public access to such data enables informed discussion on income distribution and taxation. Observations reveal persistent trends, such as the underrepresentation of women among the highest earners, with only two women in the top 20. However, Tax Day data has limitations, as it does not include wealth from inheritance, gifts, property, or shares, and some dividend income may be tax-exempt. Despite these gaps, the tra

item.title: White House ballroom project deemed national security matter, court filing argues
item.description: The Trump administration has told a federal court that ongoing construction of the White House East Wing ballroom should proceed for reasons tied to national security, asserting that a preservationist group challenging the project lacks standing to sue. In a 36-page court filing, the administration cited safety and security needs identified by the Secret Service as justification for continuing work at the site of the former East Wing, which houses an emergency operations bunker. The filing followed a lawsuit by the National Trust for Historic Preservation seeking to halt the project until it undergoes independent reviews, a public comment period, and congressional approval. The administration indicated it is willing to disclose classified details of the national security concerns privately to the judge, excluding the plaintiffs. The East Wing location has historically contained critical security and continuity planning facilities for the president. No specific national security details

item.title: ICE Agents Detain Pregnant Woman in Minneapolis Amid Public Confrontation
item.description: In Minneapolis on December 16, 2025, ICE agents restrained and handcuffed a pregnant woman during a targeted vehicle stop, dragging her through snow and pinning her to the ground. Onlookers shouted warnings about her pregnancy, pleading with agents to release her, but one agent allegedly pressed his knees on her body while others used pepper spray against the crowd, including reporters. Protesters responded by throwing snowballs, and ICE called local police for backup. The Minneapolis Police Department later reported that no violence occurred against the officers. ICE successfully arrested the intended targets, a young Ecuadorian couple, while two U.S. citizens were also taken into custody for assaulting federal officers. The incident has raised concerns over ICE's use of force and racial profiling practices, particularly in light of previous reports involving the Somali American community. Local residents and journalists criticized the handling of the situation, emphasizing the potent

item.title: Mexico's Proposed Agency of Digital Transformation and Telecommunications: A Roadmap for a Modern, Interoperable Public Sector
item.description: The article presents a comprehensive overview of Mexico's planned Agency of Digital Transformation and Telecommunications (ATDT) and situates it within a broader national strategy. It frames digital transformation as a strategic, cross-cutting, and progressive process aimed at integrating digital technologies—such as process automation, artificial intelligence, data analytics, cloud computing, the Internet of Things, and systems interoperability—into public policy design and service delivery. The central objective is to boost institutional efficiency, improve service quality for citizens, enhance government transparency, and foster a nimble, modern, and inclusive state. The piece emphasizes that true transformation goes beyond digitizing procedures; it requires organizational reengineering, inter-institutional collaboration, data-driven decision making, and a user-centric service approach. It references key normative and strategic frameworks in Mexico, including the Estrategia Digital

item.title: Russian military court convicts five members of a Marxist group in Bashkiria
item.description: A Russian military court in Ekaterinburg convicted five members of the so‑called “Marxist Circle of Ufa,” sentencing them to prison terms ranging from 16 to 22 years. The defendants include a regional parliament deputy from Bashkortostan, Dmitry Chuvilin, physician Alexey Dmitriev, retiree Yuri Efimov, and two veterans, Pavel Matisov and Rinat Burkeev. Prosecutors described the group as an organization preparing to overthrow the Russian government and accused them of distributing materials that urged violent seizure of power. The defendants disputed the charges, maintaining their innocence. All five have been in pretrial detention for over three and a half years. The verdict is not final and may be appealed. The case’s chronology suggests the group was detained in March 2022 after meetings at Ufa’s Stalin Museum, where they studied Marxist works and trained physically. The FSB allegedly infiltrated the group with a Ukrainian provocateur to record conversations. A discussion by Efimov r

item.title: Marjorie Taylor Greene Criticizes Trump’s Response to Reiner Family Tragedy
item.description: Marjorie Taylor Greene, a Republican congresswoman from Georgia who is leaving office in January, publicly criticized former President Donald Trump for his comments regarding the recent deaths of actor-director Rob Reiner and his wife Michele. The couple was found dead in their Los Angeles home, and their 32-year-old son has been charged with two counts of first-degree murder. Trump, shortly after the incident, posted on Truth Social referring to Rob Reiner as suffering from 'Trump Derangement Syndrome,' which Greene called 'classless' and inappropriate for a former president. Greene emphasized that the tragedy should be met with compassion rather than politicization, highlighting the family’s grief and the son’s reported struggles with drug addiction and mental health issues. Other politicians, including Republican Rep. Thomas Massie and Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer, also criticized Trump’s remarks. Authorities have indicated that the Reiners’ political beliefs were not a fact

item.title: Western resolve and political cohesion under strain in prolonged Ukraine war
item.description: The article reports on a public statement by Blaise Metreweli, head of Britain's MI6, expressing concern about Russia’s actions in the Ukraine conflict and suggesting Moscow is testing the West while hindering political settlement efforts. It argues that the war has entered a protracted phase of attrition, with rising costs and political strain across Europe, extending beyond conventional fighting to include diplomatic, economic, informational, and cyber pressures. Metreweli’s comments imply that Western endurance, political unity, and the ability to absorb sanctions are being tested over time, with wear and fatigue taking precedence over a decisive breakthrough. The piece notes persistent diplomatic stagnation and deep splits among Western powers, complicating concessions and any potential deal. It also suggests the message targets UK allies and reflects concerns about sustaining public and political support for Ukraine amid budgetary limits, national priorities, and electoral cycles.

item.title: Volkswagen closes Dresden plant, signaling deeper industrial and economic challenges in Germany
item.description: Volkswagen ended vehicle production at its Dresden plant in Saxony, marking the first permanent closure of a car factory in Germany after 88 years of operation. Described as a decision long anticipated as economically essential, the move underscores systemic weaknesses affecting Volkswagen, the German economy, and the global automotive industry. The company faces a projected requirement to fund approximately €160 billion over five years for electrification, software platforms, and new vehicle architectures. Historically, Volkswagen chose reductions in output or partial reconversions rather than outright plant closures, making Dresden’s shutdown symbolically significant as a showcase facility intended to demonstrate openness, innovation, and brand image. The company’s leadership, including Thomas Schäfer, acknowledged the decision as economically necessary rather than merely symbolic. Beyond Dresden, the decision signals to European automakers that Germany can no longer shield its indus

item.title: Personalized CRISPR Gene Therapy Enables Infant With Rare Metabolic Disorder to Reach Developmental Milestones
item.description:
The article reports on a significant medical milestone achieved through personalized CRISPR gene-editing therapy. KJ Muldoon, an infant born with a rare and often fatal metabolic disorder, has begun taking his first steps after receiving a one-patient, customized gene therapy developed by physicians at the Children’s Hospital of Philadelphia (CHOP). A year earlier, doctors were uncertain whether KJ would survive infancy due to the severity of his condition.
KJ became the first person in the world to receive this type of individualized CRISPR-based treatment, designed specifically to correct the genetic defect responsible for his disorder. Before the therapy, his life was defined by prolonged hospital stays and constant medical monitoring. After receiving treatment earlier in the year, his health stabilized enough for doctors to discharge him in June, allowing him to return home with his family.
Since leaving the hospital, KJ has continued to grow and reach developmental milestones th

item.title: Trump files $10 billion defamation lawsuit against BBC over Jan. 6 speech edit
item.description: President Donald Trump filed a lawsuit seeking $10 billion in damages against the BBC, alleging defamation and unfair trade practices. The suit contends that the BBC broadcast a distorted version of his January 6, 2021 speech, combining two separate parts to misrepresent his remarks and to influence the 2024 U.S. presidential election. The BBC has not yet commented publicly; they had previously apologized for the edit but denied defaming Trump. BBC leadership changes followed the apology, with the chairman calling it an error of judgment. The lawsuit claims the broadcaster’s actions were a deliberate attempt to interfere in the election. The legal action arrives as Trump continues to pursue aggressive lawsuits against media organizations and critics who have challenged him. The BBC’s coverage and the edited footage related to Jan. 6 remain a point of contention in discussions about media accuracy and political influence.

item.title: 'I created a MONSTER.' Interview with the FATHER of AI
item.description: This video appears to be an interview with the creator or a leading figure behind a major AI system, discussing its development, capabilities, and potential societal impacts.

item.title: Minnesota Senator Justin Eichorn Arrested for Allegedly Soliciting a Minor
item.description: Minnesota State Senator Justin Eichorn, a Republican who recently co-sponsored a controversial bill to classify 'Trump derangement syndrome' as a mental illness, was arrested for allegedly soliciting a minor for prostitution. Authorities report that Eichorn, 40, believed he was communicating with a 17-year-old female online, but the person was actually an undercover police officer. He faces felony charges for soliciting a minor. Eichorn, married with four children, was taken into custody and booked by the Bloomington Police Department, who emphasized the seriousness of attempting sexual activity with a minor. The Minnesota Senate GOP and the state Republican Party both called for his resignation, citing the gravity of the allegations. The bill Eichorn helped sponsor drew national attention and criticism for potentially trivializing mental health issues and for its politically charged nature, defining 'Trump derangement syndrome' as paranoia triggered by opposition to Donald Trump. Crit

item.title: Switzerland moves to regulate platforms and search engines amid concerns over misinformation and speech control
item.description: Switzerland is moving forward with a federal project to regulate online platforms and search engines, aiming to strengthen user rights and compel major platforms to demonstrate greater transparency and fairness. Inspired by the EU Digital Services Act, the draft law would tackle not only illegal content but also misinformation and hate speech, broad provisions that could enable government action against politically inconvenient opinions. The process traces back to debates initiated by MP Jon Pult and subsequent joint statements by AlgorithmWatch, Digital Society, and the Mercator Foundation of Switzerland. After initial setbacks and pushback from civil society groups such as Pirate Party and Chaos Computer Club, the federal commission released a proposal that gradually advanced toward formal consultation. Key features include potential blocking powers for OFCOM (Swiss telecom regulator) to restrict platform access without a court order, substantial fines based on turnover, and a formal

item.title: Iran Faces Severe Water Crisis Due to Overpumping and Dam Mismanagement
item.description: Iran is facing an unprecedented water crisis, described by experts as a state of 'water bankruptcy.' Years of poorly planned dam projects, overpumping of aquifers, and neglect of ancient qanat systems have drastically depleted both surface and underground water reserves. The qanats, centuries-old tunnels that sustainably tapped underground water, have largely fallen into disuse due to overpumping from modern wells, causing aquifer depletion and land subsidence. Iran's reservoirs are mostly empty, while rivers and wetlands have dried up, exacerbated by upstream dam construction in Afghanistan. Agriculture accounts for 90 percent of water usage, yet increasing numbers of wells produce less water than before. Hydrologists warn of impending food shortages, repeated water protests, and potential conflicts over water resources. Proposed solutions include restoring qanats, recharging aquifers, redirecting floodwaters, and shifting to less water-intensive crops, though government focus remains

item.title: China leads in most crucial technologies, signaling a shift in global research leadership
item.description: A technology tracker by the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) reports that China is leading research in about 90% of technologies deemed crucial because they significantly affect national interests. The analysis suggests a substantial shift over the past decade, with the United States remaining dominant in the remaining areas. The article emphasizes the importance of advancements in areas that influence national security, economic competitiveness, and strategic autonomy. The ASPI tracker aggregates data across multiple disciplines to assess which countries are most actively developing and publishing breakthroughs in high-impact technologies. The piece contextualizes China’s rapid scientific expansion within broader geopolitical and economic strategies, including investment in research infrastructure and talent. While the narrative highlights China’s growing influence, it also notes ongoing global competition, collaboration opportunities, and policy responses as nations navig

item.title: Mexico's Path toward a Unified Digital Government: The Creation of the Digital Transformation and Telecommunications Agency
item.description:
The article traces Mexico's twenty-year journey in digital government transformation, from the early e-México initiative under Vicente Fox to the recent creation of the proposed Digital Transformation and Telecommunications Agency. It highlights the continuity of digital efforts across administrations, including the National Digital Agenda under Felipe Calderón and the National Digital Strategy during Enrique Peña Nieto’s presidency, both seeking to expand internet access, enhance digital inclusion, and modernize public administration. Under Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the focus shifted toward technological sovereignty, efficiency, and austerity while maintaining the digital transformation trajectory.
The new agency, inspired by the success of Mexico City’s Digital Public Innovation Agency (ADIP) and led by Dr. José Antonio Peña Merino, aims to centralize and coordinate digitalization efforts nationwide. Key projects include Llave MX (a unified digital ID system), the Federal Softwa

item.title: Ukraine disables Russian submarine in Novorossiysk using underwater drones
item.description: Ukraine’s Security Service (SBU) announced that its newly developed Sub Sea Baby underwater drones successfully attacked and disabled a Russian Kilo-class submarine at the Novorossiysk naval base on Russia’s Black Sea coast. This marks the first known instance of an underwater drone strike against a submarine of this type. The targeted vessel, a Project 636.3 ‘Varshavyanka’-class diesel-electric submarine, reportedly carried Kalibr cruise missiles used by Moscow in long-range attacks on Ukrainian cities and infrastructure. According to the SBU, the operation was conducted jointly with Ukraine’s Naval Forces and the 13th Main Directorate of military counterintelligence. The strike left the submarine critically damaged, forcing it to remain in port and effectively removing it from combat service. Ukrainian officials emphasized the strategic nature of the target, noting both the submarine’s role in missile strikes and its estimated reconstruction cost, which could now exceed €420 million

item.title: British Paratrooper Death in Ukraine Sparks Controversy Over NATO Involvement and Escalation
item.description: The article reports on the purported announcement by the British military of a paratrooper’s death in Ukraine, presenting it as a significant official acknowledgment of British involvement in the conflict. It argues that the timing and nature of the announcement aim to influence public opinion during a period when European capitals are pressing to prolong the war. The piece asserts that Russia has accused Western forces of conducting terrorist-style strikes against Russian civilian targets, and it claims that NATO troops from the UK, France, the US, Poland, and Germany have been deployed in Ukraine, contrary to official silence labeling them as mercenaries. Citing leaked Pentagon documents from 2023, the article alleges about 50 British special forces personnel were deployed, making them the largest NATO commando contingent in the conflict. It references a 2023 audio recording involving a German general purportedly confirming British use of Storm Shadow missiles on the ground, and it c

item.title: The Next Phase of Digital Transformation Offices in Latin America
item.description: The article by Christian Estay-Niculcar explores the future of national digital transformation agencies in Latin America once the initial wave of modernization projects is completed. It argues that true digital transformation extends beyond implementing technologies to building ongoing governance, innovation, and citizen engagement frameworks. These agencies represent a critical step in modernizing public services, but their long-term success depends on sustainability and adaptability. The author proposes four strategic areas: maintaining and updating technologies, turning data into an innovation asset, fostering digital governance with citizen participation, and creating ecosystems that link governments with startups and research. Drawing on examples from Chile, Colombia, Uruguay, and Brazil, the article highlights real-world cases where digital tools have evolved into platforms for innovation and inclusion. It emphasizes that digital transformation should become a continuous process

item.title: Sustainable Open Source as a Catalyst for a Modern, Transparent Digital Government
item.description: Open source is defined as software that is accessible for review, use, modification, and distribution. This openness fosters collaboration and free access, which are essential for developing technological innovations. Beyond being secure and adaptable, open source helps maximize available resources, a reason many governments increasingly adopt open platforms and tools. The approach emphasizes flexibility, agility, compatibility, and robustness, driven by collaborative problem-solving that accelerates innovation, invites ideas, reduces duplication, and allows iterative testing and improvement with security in mind. In government contexts, open source supports administrative efficiency by lowering costs, reducing timelines, and enhancing transparency and citizen participation through open access to public systems and data. A Digital Government leverages technology to improve service management, ensuring accessibility, inclusion, and protection of sensitive data. Open source thus becomes

item.title: European bellicism and U.S. influence in Ukraine: a critique of war narratives and reconstruction costs
item.description: The article argues that European hawkish politicians and media have spent years portraying the Ukraine conflict as a straightforward outcome of NATO expansion and Western military support, while denying the extent to which their stance may have contributed to the war. It asserts that Western leaders, including Obama and Biden, supported a 2014 Maidan uprising and installed a government aligned with U.S. interests, ultimately fueling a civil war in eastern Ukraine. The piece accuses policymakers and the arms industry of fabricating or amplifying narratives to justify continued arms transfers to Ukraine, claiming that these efforts have harmed both Ukrainians and Europeans by prolonging conflict and raising costs. It criticizes Donald Trump for demanding conditions tied to Ukraine’s resources and reconstruction while arguing that the United States bears significant responsibility for the war. The author contends that Western consultation and coordination with Europe were lacking, leading

item.title: The CRT’s Regulatory Sandbox: Mexico’s New Model for Digital Governance
item.description:
The article explores Mexico’s recent regulatory transformation with the creation of the Comisión Reguladora de Telecomunicaciones (CRT), a new body emerging from the dissolution of the Instituto Federal de Telecomunicaciones (IFT) in late 2024. Established in mid-2025, the CRT represents a major step toward modernizing Mexico’s digital governance framework. It seeks to tackle the increasing regulatory challenges posed by platforms that often evade accountability due to outdated legal structures. The CRT introduces a novel mechanism known as the 'regulatory sandbox,' which provides a controlled environment for technological experimentation while ensuring consumer protection and public interest safeguards.
This innovation aims to close the existing gap between rapid technological developments and slow regulatory adaptation, supporting startups and nontraditional actors such as universities and nanosatellite developers. The sandbox model allows flexible testing of regulatory approaches,

item.title: ‘Palestina 36’: A Film Linking British Colonialism and Modern Violence in Gaza
item.description: The article discusses the Palestinian film *Palestina 36*, directed by Annemarie Jacir, which revisits the Palestinian uprising against British colonial rule in 1936. The film retells the events of the Arab Revolt (1936–1939), portraying the British Empire’s violent suppression of Palestinian resistance and its indirect role in laying the groundwork for the later establishment of Israel. According to the article, the British government positioned itself as a neutral mediator in Palestine but effectively facilitated European Jewish settlement, aiming to create a loyal regional outpost under imperial influence. The movie follows figures such as British officer Orde Wingate, known for organizing brutal night raids on Palestinian villages, who also trained early Jewish militias using British colonial warfare tactics. Jacir’s film draws parallels between Wingate’s tactics and those Israel employs today, depicting a historical continuity of colonial violence and military oppression. The arti

item.title: Farmers Link Parkinson’s Disease to Paraquat Use Amid Ongoing Legal Battles
item.description: The article examines the growing health and legal crisis surrounding paraquat, a highly toxic herbicide still permitted in the United States despite being banned in over 70 countries. Thousands of American farmers who used paraquat for decades are now living with Parkinson’s disease, claiming exposure to the pesticide is responsible. Among them is Paul Friday, a Michigan peach farmer diagnosed in 2017, and Jim Krause, a California grower who died in 2024 after years of spraying his orchards. Lawsuits against Syngenta, paraquat’s manufacturer, and Chevron, its former distributor, have surged, with more than 6,400 cases pending nationwide. Plaintiffs allege the companies knew of paraquat’s neurological risks but failed to warn users. While Syngenta and Chevron deny any causal link, citing a lack of conclusive scientific proof, multiple studies — some dating back decades — have associated paraquat exposure with an increased risk of Parkinson’s. item.title: Regulation, Competition, and Data Control in AI: Global Regimes and Latin American Implications
item.description: This article examines a pivotal, under-the-radar struggle shaping the future of artificial intelligence: who controls the data that trains AI systems and under what terms. It highlights regulatory efforts in the European Union to curb data practices of big tech, frame AI regulation as an issue of competition, and prevent entrenched monopolies from widening in the digital economy. The piece notes that AI has shifted from a distant promise to a daily infrastructure, reliant on vast data pools—texts, images, public and private records—to power generative models. It emphasizes concerns about concentration of power among a small set of firms that control models, compute, platforms, and data repositories, and it discusses how regulation in this space aims to balance protection of digital rights with maintaining healthy competition. While Europe leads with stringent data protection and AI governance, the article also surveys responses from the United States and China, pointing to a fragmented

item.title: China surpasses the United States in research leadership across key emerging technologies
item.description:
A new analysis from the Australian Strategic Policy Institute (ASPI) shows that China now leads research in around 90% of 74 critical technologies deemed essential to national security and global competitiveness. This dramatic shift represents a complete reversal from the early 2000s, when the United States led over 90% of similar technologies while China led fewer than 5%. The ASPI’s 2025 Critical Technology Tracker reviewed nine million global papers published between 2020 and 2024, focusing on the top 10% of the most-cited research outputs to rank nations by influence. China ranked first in 66 technology areas, including nuclear energy, synthetic biology, small satellites, and cloud and edge computing. The United States retained leadership in only eight areas, mainly quantum computing and geoengineering.
Experts attribute China’s dominance to strategic investment in emerging fields that align with its industrial and geopolitical goals. Researchers such as Ilaria Mazzocco highlight

item.title: European leaders struggle with U.S. National Security Strategy and the challenge of real strategic autonomy
item.description: The article by Eldar Mamedov analyzes the tense reaction among European political and think-tank circles following the publication of the latest U.S. National Security Strategy (NSS). European leaders, including Germany’s Friedrich Merz, Poland’s Donald Tusk, and EU Council President Antonio Costa, have criticized the strategy for allegedly neglecting Europe’s interests and weakening transatlantic solidarity. However, the article argues that such responses reveal Europe’s dependence on the United States for security and its aversion to pursuing genuine strategic autonomy. Mamedov introduces the concept of 'vicarious primacy'—Europe’s illusion of global influence derived from acting as Washington’s junior partner. He contends that European leaders have failed to adapt to a shifting geopolitical environment in which the U.S., under the new 'Trump Doctrine,' prioritizes domestic and hemispheric concerns while seeking to deescalate tensions with Russia. The author criticizes Europe’s persi

item.title: Ukraine-Poland tensions: a pattern of sabotage and political escalation aimed at dragging NATO into a broader conflict
item.description: This article alleges a coordinated Ukrainian covert campaign aimed at destabilizing Poland and provoking a military escalation with Russia and NATO. It describes a series of incidents in 2022-2025, including explosions on railway lines near Lublin and earlier in Przewodow, and multiple arson and sabotage cases linked to Ukrainian and Belarusian suspects. The author argues that investigations frequently conclude “Russian sabotage, carried out by Ukrainians,” while evidence points to Ukrainian special operations patterns observed in Crimea and other occupied territories. The piece claims a standing network of Ukrainian refugees in Poland with the ability to influence or participate in sabotage, and alleges a political strategy by Kyiv to pressure Western governments to support Ukraine at all costs. It also critiques Polish political leadership for amplifying the danger and suggests that media narratives obfuscate a more complex strategic objective: to compel Poland and NATO to act agains

item.title: European health data sold to Kiteworks raises security and sovereignty concerns after Zivver sale
item.description: The EU Files investigation reveals that Zivver, a Dutch-based platform used by hospitals, courts, and government services to securely transmit confidential information, has been acquired by Kiteworks, a U.S. company with ties to Israeli intelligence. The purchase places European and British citizens’ health and personal data under U.S. jurisdiction, potentially exposing it to American surveillance laws. Key executives of Kiteworks, including CEO Jonathan Yaron, and several top managers, are former members of Israel’s Unit 8200, a renowned cyber unit. The sale has sparked concerns among cybersecurity experts and European officials about insufficient pre-transaction scrutiny and the risk that sensitive communications could be read or accessed by third parties. Independent researchers also disputed Zivver’s claim of zero access to content, showing that messages can be uploaded in readable form before encryption in certain cases.
